item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description:
Over time, many Beogram devices have developed corroded DIN or RCA plugs. It’s a good idea to replace these old connectors with new, gold-plated ones. This specific Beogram 4002 (5513) came with RCA connectors. I typically use large, modern, high-quality metal plugs for replacements. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering Mechanism and Upgrade of the Tracking System with a LED Based Light Source
item.description:
With the DC motor operating correctly, the restoration of the Beogram 4002 (5513) continued with the arm lowering mechanism and tracking feedback system. The arm lowering mechanism, consisting of a solenoid and damper, was disassembled, cleaned, and lubricated. This process involved removing the damper, linkages, retaining washer, and spring. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival and a First Look
item.description:

The keypad appears barely used. However, the hood has some deep scratches, likely from improper storage. Internally, the turntable looks completely original. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the DC Motor and a Significant Improvement of the RPM Stability
item.description:
A recently acquired Beogram 4002 turntable exhibited significant speed variations during an initial performance test. The frequent and irregular drops in rotations per minute (RPM) pointed to a need for cleaning and lubrication of the DC motor. The motor was removed from its housing for servicing. The motor was then disassembled to allow for cleaning and lubrication of its bearings. Following reassembly and reinstallation of the motor, a 24-hour RPM test was conducted...

item.description:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Polishing the Hood
item.description:
The final touch in restoring a Beogram turntable is typically polishing its plexiglass cover. This particular Beogram 4002 had noticeable scratches on its cover, including a branded logo above the platter’s center. Deep scratches that can be felt by hand require an initial sanding with 220-grit sandpaper to level the surface, creating a temporarily rough appearance. If the scratches are less pronounced, starting with 320 or 400-grit sandpaper might suffice...
